locationsHub.subtitle: Every state has different insurance laws, fault systems, and deadlines. Find your state below to understand your rights and options after a car accident.
locationsHub.selectYourStateDesc: Click on your state to view detailed information about insurance requirements, fault systems, statute of limitations, and more.
locationsHub.atFaultDesc: In at-fault (tort) states, the driver who caused the accident is responsible for paying damages. You can file a claim against their insurance or sue them directly.
locationsHub.atFault1: File claim with at-fault driver's insurance
locationsHub.atFault2: Can sue for full damages including pain & suffering
locationsHub.noFaultDesc: In no-fault states, your own insurance (PIP) pays for your medical bills and lost wages regardless of who caused the accident. Lawsuits are limited.
locationsHub.noFault3: Can only sue if injuries meet threshold
locationsHub.choiceDesc: Choice states let you select between no-fault coverage or traditional at-fault coverage when you purchase your policy.
locationsHub.contributoryWarningDesc: If you're in Alabama, Maryland, North Carolina, Virginia, or Washington D.C., be aware that these jurisdictions follow pure contributory negligence rules. This means if you're found even 1% at fault for the accident, you may be completely barred from recovering any compensation.
locationsHub.contributoryWarningNote: In these states, documenting that you were not at fault is especially critical. Consider consulting with an attorney early in the process.
locationsHub.notSureDesc: Our AI Damage Analyzer can help you understand your accident regardless of which state you're in.

statePage.insuranceRequirementsDesc: {stateName} requires all drivers to carry minimum auto insurance coverage. Understanding these requirements helps ensure you're adequately protected and can inform your decisions when filing a claim.

statePage.callbackDesc: Get personalized guidance for your {stateName} accident claim.
statePage.faq1Q: What does it mean that {stateName} is a no-fault state?
statePage.faq1A: In {stateName}, no-fault means your own insurance (PIP coverage) pays for your medical expenses and lost wages after an accident, regardless of who caused it. This speeds up compensation, but limits your ability to sue unless your injuries meet certain thresholds.
statePage.faq2Q: What does it mean that {stateName} is a choice no-fault state?
statePage.faq2A: {stateName} allows you to choose between a no-fault policy (where your own PIP pays regardless of fault) or a traditional tort policy (where you can sue the at-fault driver). Each option has different premiums and recovery limitations.
statePage.faq3Q: Is {stateName} an at-fault or no-fault state?
statePage.faq3A: {stateName} is an at-fault (tort) state. This means the driver who caused the accident is responsible for paying damages. You can file a claim against their insurance or sue them directly for medical bills, lost wages, and pain and suffering.
statePage.faq4Q: How long do I have to file a car accident claim in {stateName}?
statePage.faq4A: In {stateName}, the statute of limitations for personal injury claims is {personalInjury}, and {propertyDamage} for property damage. It's important to act quickly, as missing these deadlines can permanently bar you from recovering compensation.
statePage.faq5Q: What is the minimum car insurance required in {stateName}?
statePage.faq5APipRequired: Personal Injury Protection (PIP) coverage is also mandatory.
statePage.faq5AUmOptional: Uninsured motorist coverage is optional but recommended.
statePage.faq6QContributory: What happens if I'm partially at fault for an accident in {stateName}?
statePage.faq6AContributory: {stateName} follows contributory negligence rules, which are very strict. If you are found even 1% at fault for the accident, you may be completely barred from recovering any compensation. This makes documenting fault extremely important.
statePage.faq6QComparative: Can I still recover damages if I'm partially at fault in {stateName}?
statePage.faq6APure: Yes, {stateName} uses pure comparative negligence. You can recover damages even if you're mostly at fault—your award is simply reduced by your percentage of fault.
statePage.faq6AModified50: It depends on your percentage of fault. {stateName} uses modified comparative negligence with a 50% bar. You can recover damages only if your fault is less than 50%.
statePage.faq6AModified51: It depends on your percentage of fault. {stateName} uses modified comparative negligence with a 51% bar. You can recover damages only if your fault is 50% or less.
statePage.faq7Q: How is a total loss determined in {stateName}?
statePage.faq7A: In {stateName}, your vehicle is typically considered a total loss when repair costs exceed {threshold} of its actual cash value.
statePage.faq7ATLF: Insurance companies use the Total Loss Formula (repair cost + salvage value > actual cash value) to make this determination.
statePage.faq7ATLV: Insurance companies use the percentage threshold method to make this determination.
statePage.faq8Q: Can I choose my own repair shop in {stateName}?
statePage.faq8A: Yes, you have the right to choose your own repair shop in {stateName}. Insurance companies may recommend preferred shops, but they cannot require you to use them. However, using their preferred network may streamline the claims process.
statePage.faq9Q: What is PIP insurance and how does it work in {stateName}?
statePage.faq9A: Personal Injury Protection (PIP) is mandatory in {stateName}. It covers your medical expenses and lost wages after an accident regardless of who was at fault.
statePage.faq9AAmount: The minimum PIP coverage required is {amount}.
statePage.insuranceMinimumNote: While these are the legal minimums, many experts recommend carrying higher coverage limits. Medical costs and vehicle repairs often exceed minimum coverage amounts, leaving you personally responsible for the difference.
statePage.statuteOfLimitationsDesc: The statute of limitations sets a deadline for filing legal claims after an accident. In {stateName}, you have {personalInjury} to file a personal injury lawsuit and {propertyDamage} for property damage claims.
statePage.whyTimingMattersDesc: Missing the statute of limitations deadline can permanently bar you from recovering compensation, no matter how strong your case. Additionally, evidence becomes harder to gather and witnesses' memories fade over time. Starting the claims process promptly gives you the best chance of a successful outcome.
statePage.urgentShortDeadlineText: {stateName} has one of the shortest statute of limitations in the country for personal injury claims. You must act quickly to protect your rights.
statePage.totalLossRulesDesc: When your vehicle is severely damaged, the insurance company will determine if it's more economical to repair it or declare it a total loss. In {stateName}, a vehicle is typically totaled when repair costs reach {threshold} of its actual cash value (ACV).
statePage.totalLossFormulaDesc: {stateName} uses the Total Loss Formula (TLF), where a vehicle is totaled if the repair cost plus salvage value exceeds the actual cash value. This method considers what the insurance company can recover by selling the damaged vehicle.
statePage.totalLossThresholdDesc: {stateName} uses a percentage threshold method. If repair costs exceed {threshold} of your vehicle's actual cash value, it will be declared a total loss.
statePage.optionsAfterTotalLoss: Your Options After a Total Loss
statePage.totalLossOption1: Accept the insurance payout and surrender your vehicle
statePage.totalLossOption2: Negotiate if you believe the valuation is too low
statePage.totalLossOption3: Keep your vehicle (payout will be reduced by salvage value) and receive a salvage title
statePage.whatToDoAfterTitle: What To Do After a Car Accident in {stateName}
statePage.whatToDoAfterDesc: The steps you take immediately after an accident can significantly impact your ability to recover compensation. Here's what you should do:
statePage.step1Desc: Report the accident to police and request medical assistance if anyone is injured. A police report creates official documentation.
statePage.step2Desc: Take photos of all vehicles, damage, road conditions, traffic signs, and any visible injuries. Get contact information from witnesses.
statePage.step3Desc: Get the other driver's name, phone, insurance company, policy number, license plate, and driver's license number.
statePage.step4Desc: Even if you feel fine, get checked by a doctor. Some injuries don't show symptoms immediately, and medical records are crucial for claims.
statePage.step5Desc: Notify your insurance company promptly. In {stateName}, there may be specific timeframes for reporting.
statePage.step6Desc: Avoid making statements like "I'm sorry" or "It was my fault." These can be used against you in determining liability.
statePage.dealingWithInsuranceNoFault: In {stateName}'s no-fault system, you'll typically file a claim with your own insurance company first for medical expenses and lost wages (through PIP). For property damage and additional claims, you may deal with the at-fault driver's insurer.
statePage.dealingWithInsuranceAtFault: In {stateName}, you'll likely deal with both your own insurance company and the at-fault driver's insurer. Understanding your rights and the claims process helps you navigate negotiations effectively.
statePage.right1: You can choose your own repair shop—insurers can recommend but not require their preferred shops
statePage.right2: You're entitled to a rental car if your policy or the at-fault driver's policy includes this coverage
statePage.right3: You don't have to accept the first settlement offer—you can negotiate or dispute valuations
statePage.right4: You have the right to request an independent appraisal if you disagree with the damage assessment
statePage.commonTacticsDesc: Insurance adjusters may try to minimize payouts by recording statements that can be used against you, offering quick lowball settlements, or delaying the claims process. Consider consulting with an attorney before accepting any settlement, especially for significant injuries.

settlementCalcPage.faq1Q: How are car accident settlements calculated?
settlementCalcPage.faq1A: Car accident settlements are typically calculated by adding up all your economic damages (medical bills, lost wages, property damage) and then multiplying by a factor of 1.5 to 5 to account for pain and suffering. The multiplier depends on injury severity—minor injuries use lower multipliers, while severe or permanent injuries use higher ones. This gives you an estimated settlement range, though actual amounts vary based on liability, insurance limits, and negotiation.
settlementCalcPage.faq2Q: What is the average settlement for a car accident?
settlementCalcPage.faq2A: Average car accident settlements vary widely based on injury severity. Minor injuries like whiplash typically settle for $10,000-$25,000. Moderate injuries involving some medical treatment average $25,000-$100,000. Severe injuries requiring surgery or extended treatment can range from $100,000 to $500,000 or more. Cases involving permanent disability or wrongful death often exceed $1 million. These are general ranges—your specific case depends on medical costs, lost income, liability, and available insurance coverage.
settlementCalcPage.faq3Q: What factors affect car accident settlement amounts?
settlementCalcPage.faq3A: Key factors include: injury severity and required treatment, total medical expenses, lost wages and future earning capacity, property damage, evidence of fault, available insurance coverage, permanent impairment or disability, impact on daily life, documentation quality, and the jurisdiction where the accident occurred. Cases with clear liability (like rear-end collisions) and well-documented injuries typically result in higher settlements.
settlementCalcPage.faq4Q: How long does it take to get a car accident settlement?
settlementCalcPage.faq4A: Simple cases with minor injuries and clear liability may settle in 2-4 months. Moderate injury cases typically take 6-12 months. Severe injury cases often require 1-2 years or longer, especially if litigation is involved. Factors affecting timeline include: reaching maximum medical improvement, gathering all documentation, negotiation process, and whether a lawsuit becomes necessary.
settlementCalcPage.faq5Q: Should I accept the insurance company's first offer?
settlementCalcPage.faq5A: Generally, no. First offers are typically lowball offers designed to settle cheaply. Insurance adjusters often offer 25-50% less than what a claim is actually worth. Before accepting, ensure you've reached maximum medical improvement, gathered all bills and documentation, calculated lost wages, and considered future medical needs. Consulting with a personal injury attorney (usually free) can help you understand if an offer is fair.
settlementCalcPage.faq6Q: What is pain and suffering worth in a settlement?
settlementCalcPage.faq6A: Pain and suffering is typically calculated using a multiplier method (1.5x to 5x your economic damages) or a per diem method (daily rate × days of recovery). Minor soft tissue injuries might use a 1.5-2x multiplier. Moderate injuries with some lasting effects use 2-3x. Severe injuries with significant impact use 3-4x. Permanent or catastrophic injuries may use 5x or higher. Documented pain levels, treatment duration, and impact on quality of life all affect this calculation.
settlementCalcPage.faq7Q: Do I need a lawyer to get a fair settlement?
settlementCalcPage.faq7A: While not required, statistics show that accident victims represented by attorneys typically receive 3-4 times higher settlements than those who negotiate alone, even after attorney fees. Attorneys are particularly valuable for: serious injuries, disputed liability, uncooperative insurance companies, complex medical situations, and cases involving multiple parties. Most personal injury attorneys offer free consultations and work on contingency (no upfront cost).
settlementCalcPage.faq8Q: What if my medical bills exceed the at-fault driver's insurance limits?
settlementCalcPage.faq8A: If the at-fault driver's insurance is insufficient, you have several options: file a claim with your own underinsured motorist (UIM) coverage, use your health insurance or MedPay coverage, sue the at-fault driver personally (though collecting may be difficult), or negotiate medical liens with providers. Having adequate UIM coverage on your own policy is the best protection against underinsured drivers.

faqs.faq2Q: Can I dispute my car being totaled?
faqs.faq2A: Yes, you can dispute the valuation by providing comparable vehicle listings, getting independent appraisals, and documenting any unique features or recent upgrades to your car.

faqs.faq1Q: Who is at fault in a T-bone accident?
faqs.faq1A: Usually the driver who failed to yield right-of-way: running red lights, ignoring stop signs, or making unsafe left turns. However, fault can be shared if the other driver was speeding or ran a yellow light.
faqs.faq2Q: Why are T-bone accidents so dangerous?
faqs.faq2A: Side-impact crashes are especially dangerous because the side of a car offers less protection than the front or rear. Occupants on the struck side face direct impact with less crumple zone to absorb force.
faqs.faq3Q: What is the average T-bone accident settlement?
faqs.faq3A: Property damage only: $5,000-$15,000. With injuries: $25,000-$75,000. Serious injuries (TBI, spinal): $100,000-$500,000+. Settlements vary significantly based on injury severity and fault.
faqs.faq4Q: How do I prove the other driver ran a red light?
faqs.faq4A: Evidence includes: traffic camera footage, dashcam video, witness statements, police report, intersection surveillance cameras, and accident reconstruction experts for serious cases.

faqs.faq1Q: What is the most dangerous highway in America?
faqs.faq1A: I-95 consistently ranks as one of the deadliest, spanning from Miami to Maine. In terms of fatality rate per mile, I-4 in Florida and I-10 in Texas also rank extremely high. Rural interstates often have higher death rates due to speed and distance from trauma centers.
faqs.faq2Q: Does where an accident happens affect my claim?
faqs.faq2A: Yes. Accidents in known dangerous areas can help establish negligence (e.g., a city knew about a dangerous intersection). Traffic camera footage, road condition reports, and accident history can all strengthen your claim.
faqs.faq3Q: Can I sue a city for a dangerous road?
faqs.faq3A: Potentially, yes. If a road defect, poor signage, or known dangerous condition contributed to your accident, you may have a claim against the government entity responsible. These claims have strict notice requirements and shorter deadlines.
faqs.faq4Q: Why do some intersections have so many accidents?
faqs.faq4A: Common factors include: poor visibility, confusing lane markings, short yellow light timing, lack of turn signals, high traffic volume, and poor road design. Many dangerous intersections have been known problems for years.

faqs.faq1Q: Am I at fault if I crash in bad weather?
faqs.faq1A: Weather itself isn't an excuse. Drivers are expected to adjust speed and following distance for conditions. If you were driving too fast for conditions, you can be found at fault even if the weather caused you to lose control.
faqs.faq2Q: Can I claim for an accident caused by rain or ice?
faqs.faq2A: Yes, but liability depends on the circumstances. Another driver may be at fault if they were driving too fast for conditions. Road authorities can sometimes be liable for failing to treat icy roads or fix drainage issues.
faqs.faq3Q: Does weather affect my settlement amount?
faqs.faq3A: It can. If weather was a contributing factor and the other driver should have adjusted their driving, it strengthens your case. Insurance adjusters consider whether reasonable precautions were taken.
faqs.faq4Q: What if I hit someone because I hydroplaned?
faqs.faq4A: You may be found at fault. Courts generally hold that drivers should slow down in wet conditions. However, if a road defect (poor drainage, standing water) contributed, you might have a claim against the road authority.

faqs.faq1Q: What is the difference between at-fault and no-fault states?
faqs.faq1A: In at-fault (tort) states, the driver who caused the accident pays for damages through their liability insurance. In no-fault states, each driver's own insurance pays their medical bills regardless of fault, with lawsuits limited to serious injuries.
faqs.faq2A: Florida, Michigan, New Jersey, New York, Pennsylvania, Hawaii, Kansas, Kentucky, Massachusetts, Minnesota, North Dakota, and Utah have no-fault systems. Puerto Rico also uses no-fault. Requirements and thresholds vary by state.
faqs.faq3Q: Can I sue in a no-fault state?
faqs.faq3A: Yes, but only if injuries meet a threshold. States use either a monetary threshold (medical bills exceed a certain amount) or verbal threshold (specific serious injuries like fractures, permanent injury, or disfigurement).
faqs.faq4Q: How does comparative negligence affect my claim?
faqs.faq4A: In pure comparative states, you can recover damages minus your fault percentage (even at 99% fault). In modified comparative states, you can't recover if you're more than 50% (or 51%) at fault. A few states still use contributory negligence where any fault bars recovery.
faqs.faq5Q: What is the statute of limitations for car accidents?
faqs.faq5A: Most states allow 2-3 years to file a lawsuit after a car accident. Some states have shorter deadlines (1 year in Kentucky and Louisiana). Claims against government entities often have much shorter notice requirements (sometimes 30-180 days).

totalLossCalcPage.understandingTitle: Understanding Total Loss Car Insurance Claims
totalLossCalcPage.understandingIntro: When your vehicle is involved in an accident, one of the most important determinations is whether the car is a "total loss" or if it can be repaired. This decision significantly impacts your insurance claim, your finances, and your next steps. Our total loss calculator helps you understand what to expect before the insurance company makes their decision.
totalLossCalcPage.whatIsTotalLossTitle: What Is a Total Loss Vehicle?
totalLossCalcPage.whatIsTotalLossP1: A total loss, also called a "totaled car," occurs when the cost to repair your vehicle exceeds a certain percentage of its actual cash value (ACV). The ACV represents what your car was worth immediately before the accident, considering factors like age, mileage, condition, and local market prices.
totalLossCalcPage.whatIsTotalLossP2: Insurance companies declare vehicles as total losses because it's more economically sensible to pay you the car's value than to spend more on repairs. However, the threshold for this determination varies significantly depending on your state and insurance company.
totalLossCalcPage.thresholdsTitle: How Total Loss Thresholds Work by State
totalLossCalcPage.thresholdsIntro: States regulate total loss determinations in two primary ways:
totalLossCalcPage.percentageMethodDesc: Most states use a fixed percentage threshold, typically between 70% and 100%. If repair costs exceed this percentage of the vehicle's ACV, it's declared a total loss. For example, in a state with a 75% threshold, a $20,000 car would be totaled if repairs exceed $15,000.
totalLossCalcPage.tlfMethodDesc: Some states use the Total Loss Formula, where repair cost plus salvage value must exceed the ACV. This method considers what the damaged vehicle could sell for, making the calculation more nuanced but often resulting in fewer total loss declarations.
totalLossCalcPage.processIntro: Understanding the total loss process helps you prepare for negotiations and ensure you receive fair compensation:
totalLossCalcPage.processStep1Desc: An adjuster inspects your vehicle and estimates repair costs. They'll also photograph damage and document the vehicle's condition.
totalLossCalcPage.processStep2Desc: The insurance company determines your vehicle's ACV using valuation services and comparable sales data from your local market.
totalLossCalcPage.processStep3Desc: Based on repair estimates, ACV, and your state's threshold, the insurer determines if the vehicle is a total loss.
totalLossCalcPage.processStep4Desc: You receive an offer for the ACV minus your deductible. You can accept, negotiate, or dispute the valuation.
totalLossCalcPage.processStep5Desc: Upon accepting the settlement, you sign over the title. The vehicle goes to salvage unless you choose to keep it.
totalLossCalcPage.disputeTitle: How to Dispute a Low Total Loss Offer
totalLossCalcPage.disputeIntro: Insurance companies don't always offer fair settlements. If you believe your vehicle is worth more than the initial offer, you have every right to negotiate. Here's how to build a strong case:
totalLossCalcPage.dispute1: Gather comparable sales: Find recent listings and sales of similar vehicles in your area from Kelley Blue Book, Edmunds, AutoTrader, and local dealerships.
totalLossCalcPage.dispute2: Document your vehicle's condition: Provide evidence of low mileage, recent maintenance, new tires, or upgrades that add value.
totalLossCalcPage.dispute3: Get multiple valuations: Request quotes from dealers and use multiple valuation tools to establish a fair range.
totalLossCalcPage.dispute4: Review the insurer's valuation report: Ask for the CCC, Mitchell, or Audatex report they used and check for errors.
totalLossCalcPage.dispute5: Hire an independent appraiser: For significant disputes, a professional appraisal can provide leverage.
totalLossCalcPage.dispute6: File a complaint: If negotiations fail, contact your state's insurance commissioner.
totalLossCalcPage.gapInsuranceIntro: Gap insurance (Guaranteed Asset Protection) is crucial if you owe more on your car loan than the vehicle is worth. This is common for:
totalLossCalcPage.gap2: Loans with little or no down payment
totalLossCalcPage.gap4: Vehicles that were purchased above market value
totalLossCalcPage.gapInsuranceNote: Without gap insurance, you're responsible for paying the difference between the insurance settlement and your remaining loan balance. Our calculator shows this "gap amount" if you enter your current loan balance.
totalLossCalcPage.keepVehicleIntro: In most states, you can choose to keep your totaled vehicle. The insurance company will deduct the salvage value from your settlement. However, consider these factors:
totalLossCalcPage.keep1: Your car will receive a salvage or rebuilt title, significantly reducing resale value
totalLossCalcPage.keep2: Some insurers won't provide comprehensive/collision coverage on salvage title vehicles
totalLossCalcPage.keep3: You'll need to pass a rebuilt vehicle inspection before driving it legally
totalLossCalcPage.keep4: Repairs may reveal additional hidden damage that increases costs
totalLossCalcPage.keep5: Future safety and reliability concerns should be evaluated by a mechanic

totalLossCalcPage.faq1Q: What does 'total loss' mean for a car?
totalLossCalcPage.faq1A: A total loss occurs when the cost to repair your vehicle exceeds a certain percentage of its actual cash value (ACV). Most insurance companies use a threshold between 70-80%, though some states have specific laws. When your car is declared a total loss, the insurance company will pay you the vehicle's ACV minus your deductible instead of paying for repairs.
totalLossCalcPage.faq2Q: How do insurance companies calculate total loss value?
totalLossCalcPage.faq2A: Insurance companies calculate total loss value using your vehicle's Actual Cash Value (ACV), which considers the pre-accident market value, mileage, condition, optional equipment, and recent comparable sales in your area. They typically use valuation services like CCC, Mitchell, or Audatex to determine this value.
totalLossCalcPage.faq3Q: Can I dispute a total loss settlement offer?
totalLossCalcPage.faq3A: Yes, you can and should dispute a low total loss offer. Gather evidence including recent comparable sales from sites like Kelley Blue Book, Edmunds, and local dealer listings. Document any upgrades or recent maintenance. You can also hire an independent appraiser or file a complaint with your state's insurance commissioner.
totalLossCalcPage.faq4Q: What is the total loss threshold in my state?
totalLossCalcPage.faq4A: Total loss thresholds vary by state, typically ranging from 70% to 100% of the vehicle's ACV. Some states use a Total Loss Formula (TLF) where repair cost + salvage value must exceed the ACV. Check your state's specific regulations or ask your insurance company for the threshold they use.
totalLossCalcPage.faq5Q: Do I get to keep my car if it's totaled?
totalLossCalcPage.faq5A: In most cases, yes, you can keep your totaled car by accepting a reduced settlement (the ACV minus salvage value). You'll receive a salvage title, which affects future resale value and may require a rebuilt title inspection before the car can be legally driven again. Some states don't allow this option for severely damaged vehicles.
totalLossCalcPage.faq6Q: How long does the total loss settlement process take?
totalLossCalcPage.faq6A: The total loss settlement process typically takes 2-4 weeks from the date of the accident. This includes the initial inspection (1-3 days), valuation process (3-5 days), negotiation period (varies), and payment processing (3-7 days). Complex cases or disputes can extend this timeline significantly.
totalLossCalcPage.faq7Q: Will gap insurance help if my car is totaled?
totalLossCalcPage.faq7A: Yes, gap insurance covers the difference between what you owe on your car loan and what the insurance company pays for the total loss. This is especially valuable for new cars that depreciate quickly or if you made a small down payment. Gap insurance is typically purchased when you buy or lease the vehicle.
totalLossCalcPage.faq8Q: What happens to my car loan if my car is totaled?
totalLossCalcPage.faq8A: You're still responsible for paying off your car loan even if your car is totaled. The insurance settlement goes first to your lienholder (the bank or finance company). If the settlement doesn't cover the full loan balance, you'll owe the difference unless you have gap insurance.
